tossups.question: Borde, Vilenkin and another scientist name a theorem that allows this process to apparently violate the weak energy condition by having a boundary at a finite beginning of time. It was originally posited that the Higgs field was the driving force behind this process but it is now though to be driven by a scalar field that may not have a zero energy state.  Uniformity of regions separated by light-time greater than the age of the universe and the closeness of the universe density to the critical value were the main reasons for positing it, and this process occurred from 10^-36 and 10^-32 seconds after the Big Bang. For 10 points, name this theory proposed by Alan Guth which proposes a brief period of very rapid expansion in the early universe.

This man's time in Italy saw the creation of his portrait of Emmanuel Philibert of Savoy, while the religious works of his early period include St. Martin Dividing His Cloak and The Crowning with Thorns. In a self-portrait, he cradles a gold chain given to him by his patron. Engravers in this artist's home city adapted his many drawings and quick portraits to create the prints which make up his Iconography. This creator of Self Portrait with Sunflower man also painted a portrait in which the subject wears a slanted, full-brimmed black hat and is accompanied by a horse and two courtiers; that work depicts the title monarch on a hunt, and this man also made an equestrian portrait of that monarch.  A student of Peter Paul Rubens, for 10 points, name this Flemish painter from Antwerp known for his many portraits of the English King Charles I.

One member of this group had a wife named Evadne, who jumped on his funeral pyre. Two members of this group joined forces after a king promised them his daughters because a seer told him to marry them off to a boar and a lion. Thersander and Alcmaeon were members of a group that succeeded where this one failed, called the Epigoni. A clairvoyant member of this group was swallowed by the earth after an incident in which Tydeus ate Melanippus' brains. Including Capaneus,  Parthenopaeus, and Amphiarus, this group sacrificed a bull over a black shield and swore an oath to Phobos immediately before rushing the gates of their target city. After this group's incursion, Antigone attempted to bury it's leader. For 10 points, name this group of warriors lead by Polynices, which attempted to take over the namesake mythological city once led by his father Oedipus.
tossups.answer: The Seven Against Thebes [accept things like Polynices' army before mention]
tossups.answer_formatted: The Seven Against Thebes [accept things like Polynices' army before mention]

tossups.question: This system was transplanted to Britain due to the recommendations of the Northcote-Trevelyan report, and so-called "mean" people were barred from participating in this process. The winner of this process stood directly underneath the statue of a turtle at the ceremony afterwards, and those that succeeded at the district level were exempt from corporal punishment. Those who managed to get through this process could wear a badge containing a crane or pheasant on their clothing, and the submissions were recopied so that handwriting was not recognizable. It superseded the nine-rank system, and the eight-legged essay was an outgrowth of it. An attempt to modernize it was part of the Hundred Days reform, and it focused on the "Six Arts", "Five Studies", and rote memorization of the Confucian classics. For 10 points, name this ancient Chinese testing system by which civil servants were selected.
tossups.answer: Civil Service Imperial Examination System [or Literally Anything in Chinese sounding like keju, accept equivalents, accept anything related to China and "civil service" before mention]
tossups.answer_formatted: Civil Service Imperial Examination System [or Literally Anything in Chinese sounding like keju, accept equivalents, accept anything related to China or civil service" before mention]
acceptable: Literally Anything in Chinese sounding like keju, accept equivalents, accept anything related to China

tossups.question: One writer from this country wrote the collections Ethnic Radio and Subhuman Redneck Poems, and repeated the line, "Axe-fall, echo and silence," in his poem "Noonday Axeman." In a novel by an author born in this country, Mr. Collyer is revealed to have been deep in debt, and Henny drinks poisoned tea to escape her marriage to Sam Pollitt. This country is the birthplace of the author of The Man Who Loved Children, Christina Stead, as well as the adopted home of J. M. Coetzee. This country is home to the poet Les Murray, and the birthplace of expatriate critics such as Clive James, Robert Hughes, and Germaine Greer. For 10 points, name this country whose "bush poets," such as Banjo Paterson, wrote about life in the Outback.

One experiment performed by this man had male and female college students read two incongruent dispositions of a person and attempt to resolve them. With Ebenholz, this man posited the principle of associative symmetry to explain the direction of associative recall. Another experiment performed by this thinker, which was published in Groups, Leadership, and Men and was designed to test the conclusions of Muzafar Sharif's use of the autokinetic effect, put a group of confederates into the pool of participants to influence their choices. For 10 points, name this psychologist who performed an experiment involving a card with three different lengths of lines to test conformity.

One charter of this city declared music to be a state religion and divided it into nine economic corporations and one superior corporation of geniuses. During World War II, the strongest point of the German Ingrid Line was at Klana near this city. This city was a longstanding corpus separatum in the Habsburg Empire ever since Maria Theresa attached it to Hungary. This city was taken during "Bloody Christmas" when the Regency of Carnaro was ousted per the provisions of a treaty which awarded nearby Susak to Yugoslavia, the Treaty of Rapallo. This Adriatic city, which was not included in the provisions of the 1915 Treaty of London, became a Free State for four years in the interwar period before being annexed by the Treaty of Rome to Italy. For 10 points, name this seaport once taken over by the poet Gabriel D'Annunzio, the principal seaport of Croatia.

The IR spectrum of this substance has a degenerate bending mode at 546 inverse centimeters, an inactive symmetric stretch, and an antisymmetric stretch mode at 2345 inverse centimeters. This substance is produced as a byproduct of quicklime production, and algae bioreactors are designed primarily to absorb this substance. Above 300 degrees Kelvin and 7.4 megapascals, this substance forms a supercritical fluid that is used for decaffeination reactions and extraction of hydrocarbons from soil. The Keeling Curve gives the levels of this substance in the atmosphere, and adding this substance to a solution of Grignard reagents is a quick method of synthesizing carboxylates. For 10 points, name this substance, the primary greenhouse gas produced alongside water in combustion reactions.

The final chapter of this work offers some "concluding applications" and argues that relations are "enjoyed in a moral spirit, when they are regarded as sacred in themselves." One chapter of this work claims that "if your predicates are anthropomorphisms, the subject of them is an anthropomorphism too." Another chapter of this work analyzes the significance of celibacy and "monachism," and holds that "the natural principle of marriage... is excluded from heaven." This work's second part is dedicated to contradictions in the Sacraments, Trinity, and the existence, revelation, and nature of God, while its first part claims that the title phenomenon is merely "spiritual Judaism." For 10 points, identify this work which claims that "the secret of theology is anthropology," in arguing that "we should raise ourselves above" the title religion, the most famous work of Ludwig Feurbach.

This novel's protagonist witnesses a figure leaning out of a top floor window just before he dies. Earlier, he attempted to bribe the Flogger so he would stop whipping Willem and Franz, and both the protagonist and Block, a client of the lawyer Dr. Huld, attract a maid with webbed hands named Leni. This novel's protagonist doesn't find an Italian man at the cathedral, but hears a priest's parable about a man who sits outside of a guarded door for a year before dying. FrÃ¤ulein Montag moves in with FrÃ¤ulein BÃ¼rstner in this novel, in which neither the painter Titorelli nor Uncle Karl can offer useful legal advice. Two men take the protagonist to a quarry and stab him in, for 10 points, what novel that sees Josef K. accused of an unknown crime, a work of Franz Kafka.

A condition which includes motor and sensory neuropathy and an absence of this structure is linked to mutations in SLC12A6. A lesion of the posterior part of this structure is responsible for a condition in which people are unable to distinguish their fingers, known as Gerstmann's syndrome. Hypoplasia of this structure is one of the elements of CRASH syndrome, and Probst bundles are a sign of its absence. Ralph Holloway found that this structure is larger in women than men. This structure contains a body, genu, and splenium, and it contains a large collection of commissural fibers. Alien hand syndrome can result from lesions in it, and cutting it is a last-ditch treatment for epilepsy. For 10 points, name this bundle of neural fibers which connects the two hemispheres of the brain together.

In the conclusion of this play, one character asks, "can I leave the virtuous path those eyes illuminate?" That character is earlier alleged to have injured someone else in a pistol duel by Crabtree. In this play, Moses arranges a meeting between Oliver and the moneylender Mr. Premium. Sir Peter concludes an argument with his wife by stating that they should separate after she asks for two hundred pounds. Snake is told to forge untruthful letters by the main character, but he is bribed into doublecrossing her at the end of this play. The main character of this play plots to separate Peter Teazle's ward Maria from Charles Surface so that she can have him for herself. For 10 points, name this Richard Sheridan play focusing on the malicious gossip spread by Lady Sneerwell.

Parallel, millimeter-thin layers of mineral that occur perpendicular to the "b" crystallographic axis form a type of twinning named for one mineral of this class that also exhibits twinning via the Manebach, Baveno, and Carlsbad laws. At the low anorthite end of a series, Albite is a transition between two classes of this mineral. Minerals of this type with only Potassium or Sodium as metals are known as the alkali class of these tectosilicate minerals whose other major class forms the continuous branch of the Bowen's reaction series. The Calcium rich Plagioclase and the Potassium rich Orthoclase are the most observed members of, for 10 points, which mineral class which is a 6 on the Mohs scale of hardness and whose name comes from the German for Field Rock.

One room in this building features tapestries depicting the history of Abraham, the return of Sarah, and St. Peter healing the lame man at the beautiful gate of the Temple. That room is the Jerusalem Chamber, which was added by Nicholas de Litlyngton. Martin Luther King Jr, and Dietrich Boenhoffer are among the 10 martyrs depicted in statues on the west gate of this building. The south transept of this building, which is also home to the Stone of Scone, contains a section which commemorates the Bronte sisters, Ben Johnson, and Geoffrey Chaucer, called the Poets corner. Begun under Edward the Confessor and rebuilt under Henry III, for 10 points, identify this church in London which is used for the coronation of British Monarchs.

This author remembers an overheard airplane conversation about a child born into a primitive tribe who can answer any question, in the story "Another Pioneer." In a longer work, this writer included David Cusk, whose intense fear of sweating causes constant sweating, and a former wastoid who studies all night and treks through the snow to a recruiting office, "Irrelevant" Chris Fogle. President Johnny Gentle and the war-game Eschaton feature in one of his novels, which follows Don Gately's stay at the clinic Ennet House and Hal Incandenza's time at the Enfield Tennis Academy. The essay "E Unibas Plurum" and a book about the tedium experienced by IRS auditors were written by this figure who wrote about "The Entertainment," a dangerously addictive video cartridge. For 10 points, name this author of The Pale King and Infinite Jest.

One general in this battle exclaimed 'We are in a chamber pot, and we're going to be shit on,' upon gaining command. Jean-Auguste Margueritte was injured during a cavalry charge on the city of Floing during this battle. Pontoon bridges were constructed by the victorious side in an attempt to flank their foes at Bazeilles. The last stage of this battle took place when the losing side retreated to the Bois de Garrene. Attempts at withdrawal by the losing side were thwarted by heavy enemy artillery fire from Krupp-made cannons. General Ducrot took command of one side after MacMahon was injured early in this battle. This battle was precipitated by the siege of Metz and the subsequent deployment of the Army of Chalons. For 10 points, name this battle in which Napoleon III was captured, a massive defeat for French forces in the Franco-Prussian War.

A two time Olympic champion and current commentator for this sport is Dick Button, who invented his own camel position. Tournaments such as the TrophÃ© Eric Bompard, NHK Trophy, and Cup of China are preliminary events leading to a Grand Prix Finals. Another major tournament is the Four Continents Championships, which were won in 2011 by the America's Davis & White for Dance, China's Pang & Tong for Pairs, and Japan's Miki Ando and Daisuke Takahashi respectively for Women's and Men's Singles. Yuna Kim won the Women's Gold medal for this sport at the 2010 Olympics, where another said he won the Platinum Medal because he, Evgeni Plushenko, had performed quadruaple jumps, while the gold medalist, Evan Lysachek, hadn't. For 10 points, name this artistic winter sport that involves spinning and jumping while skating on ice.
tossups.answer: Olympic Figure Skating [prompt on "skating" or "ice skating"]

tossups.question: An early theological addition to the practice of this faith was the so-called "Black Rubric," and in 1931, leaders of this faith hashed out an agreement with the Union of Utrecht at the Bonn Conference. The question of what clothes are to be worn by officials within this faith gave rise to its Admonitions controversy. Richard Hooker penned a notable apologetics for this faith, which briefly saw its primary devotional text banned and replaced by a Directory for the Public Worship of God. The central document of this denomination was attacked by the Tractarians, some of whom, like John Henry Newman, eventually left this faith for Catholicism. Relying on the Book of Common Prayer for its worship, for 10 points, identify this Christian denomination that derives its spiritual authority from the Thirty-Nine Articles, the official Christian faith of a certain European island nation.
tossups.answer: Anglicanism or the Church of England
acceptable: Anglicanism or the Church of England
Anglicanism or the Church of England

tossups.question: One section of Profiles In Courage details an incident in which the vice-presidential winner of this election told off Roscoe Conkling. Peter Cooper represented the Greenback party during this event. An attempt to reelect General John Logan to the Senate by the Illinois legislature led to the impartial Justice David Davis being replaced by Joseph P. Bradley. The legality of a vote cast by a postmaster in Oregon was questioned along with 19 others. Ending Reconstruction was a compromise in the year following this election that was a concession won by the losing candidate, Samuel Tilden. For 10 points, name this 19th century American presidential election controversially settled by committee and won by Rutherford B. Hayes.
tossups.answer: United States Presidential Election of 1876 [or equivalents such as early buzzes of Rutherford B. Hayes defeats Samuel J. Tilden for president]
tossups.answer_formatted: United States Presidential Election of 1876 [or equivalents such as early buzzes of Rutherford B. Hayes defeats Samuel J. Tilden for president]
acceptable: equivalents such as early buzzes of Rutherford B. Hayes defeats Samuel J. Tilden for president

tossups.question: After much persuasion, this man was convinced by pianist Otakar Hollman to write a Capriccio for Piano Left-Hand and a Chamber Ensemble. A "Starodavny" and "Pozezhnani" are two of his Lachian Dances, while his first string quartet was inspired by Tolstoy's novella Kreutzer Sonata. His most famous orchestral work opens with an Allegretto fanfare scored only for percussion and an expanded brass section, before going on to depict "The Queen's Monastery" and "The Street Leading to the Castle." That work was written for the Sokol Festival, and this man's greatest champion in the conducting world was Sir Charles Mackerras. He also composed a liturgical work with movements titled "Slava" and "Svet" rather than the normal Latin titles, as that work was written in Old Church Slavonic. For 10 points, name this Czech composer of a noted Sinfonietta and the Glagolitic Mass.

Operation Model 5 was an attempt to take out several weapons positions during the early stages of this war. One side of this war was airlifted weapons in Operation Nickel Grass. An important battle in this war was fought at a position called the Chinese Farm. UN Resolutions 338 and 339 called for an end to this conflict, which began when one side launched Operation Badr. After this war, one side withdrew to the Purple Line, and this war saw three battles of Mount Hermon. This war began with an event called "the Crossing", in which countries led by Hafiz Al-Assad and Anwar Sadat launched a preemptive strike against a nation that had won the Six-day War a few years earlier. For 10 points, name this Israeli-Arab war that began on the holiest day of the Jewish calendar.
tossups.answer: Yom Kippur War or October War or Ramadan War
tossups.answer_formatted: Yom Kippur War or October War or Ramadan War
acceptable: Yom Kippur War or October War or Ramadan War
Yom Kippur War or October War or Ramadan War

bonuses.leadin: Identify these early American portraitists, for 10 points each:
parts: This man created both Landsdowne and Athaneum portraits of George Washington, the latter of which appears on the U.S. One-Dollar Bill.

This man depicted himself lifting up a red curtain to reveal a vast gallery in The Artist in his Museum. He also had some sons named Raphael and Rembrandt and painted some people digging up bones in Exhumation of the Mastodon.
In addition to depicting Richard Montgomery's death during the failed invasion of Canada, this man painted The Declaration of Independence, which now hangs in the U.S. Capitol Rotunda

bonuses.leadin: Name these authors of travel narratives, for 10 points each:
parts: He wrote about his travels in Sketches of Etruscan Places and Mornings in Mexico, but he's more famous for writing about a sexually frustrated woman having an affair with Oliver Mellors in Lady Chatterly's Lover.
His Travels Through France and Italy is much less well known than his picaresque novel about an adventurer who marries the beautiful Narcissa in Roderick Random.
This gigantic travelogue by Dame Rebecca West details her journeys through Yugoslavia.

bonuses.leadin: This event was precipitated by the arrest of John Macarthur. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this revolt that Major Johnston's forces set up a government that lasted two years before the arrival of Lachlan Macquarie. It deposed a governor who tried to regulate officers' private trading.
The New South Wales Corps that provided the muscle for the Rum Rebellion in Sydney was based in this modern-day Southern Hemisphere island nation.

The rebels found this man trying to hide under a bed. Before being deposed as Governor of New South Wales, this Royal Navy officer was betrayed by Fletcher Christian during the mutiny on the HMS Bounty.

bonuses.leadin: An early example of these devices consisted of a glass jar on which 2 metal plates were placed and which was often filled with water, the Leyden jar. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these devices, which store charge between two parallel plates. Their namesake quantity, which is measured in Farads, is the ratio between the stored charge and the Voltage.
These surfaces along which the gradient of the Electric Field is zero, are always perpendicular to the Electric field lines. The plates of a capacitor are these surfaces with delta V =0.
Near the edges of Capacitors this type of Electric Field forms which is no longer parallel between the plates.

bonuses.leadin: The first work in his first short story collection was named for a Gogol work. For 10 points:
answers: Lu Xun or Lu Hsun or Zhou Shuren or Chou Shujen
The True Story of Ah-Q or AhQ Zhenzhuan
Mao Dun or Mao Tun or Shen Dehong or Shen Yanbing
parts: Name this modern Chinese writer who wrote about a man who believes the people of his village, including Mr. Chao and his own elder brother are cannibals in "A Madman's Diary" from his Call to Arms.
The longest section of Lu Xun's Call to Arms is devoted to this work where the protagonist is a liar and laughingstock who executed during the Xinhai Revolution after failing to join in.
Lu Xun published many works in the "New Wave of Novels" column edited by this man. The first PRC Culture Minister, he is also known for writing Spring Silkworms and Midnight.
answers_formatted: Lu Xun or Lu Hsun or Zhou Shuren or Chou Shujen
The True Story of Ah-Q or AhQ Zhenzhuan
Mao Dun or Mao Tun or Shen Dehong or Shen Yanbing
acceptable: Lu Xun or Lu Hsun or Zhou Shuren or Chou Shujen
Lu Xun or Lu Hsun or Zhou Shuren or Chou Shujen
The True Story of Ah-Q or AhQ Zhenzhuan
True Story of Ah-Q or AhQ Zhenzhuan
Mao Dun or Mao Tun or Shen Dehong or Shen Yanbing
Mao Dun or Mao Tun or Shen Dehong or Shen Yanbing

bonuses.leadin: In one section of this work, the author tells the story of a schoolteacher who attempted to teach him that God made the flowers a pretty color for human eyes, to which he vehemently disagreed. For 10 points each:
answers: God is not Great: How Religion Poisons Everything
parts: Identify this atheist tome which ends by calling for the need for a new enlightenment. Another section discusses how Saddam Hussein became more and more fanatically religious as he took power.
This journalist, polemicist, and former contributor to Vanity Fair magazine wrote God is Not Great. His essays are collected in the volume Arguably.
Hitchens defends himself against people like William Lane Craig, who work in this subfield of theology. This field is concerned with defending faith using philosophical arguments.
answers_formatted: God is not Great: How Religion Poisons Everything
acceptable: God is not Great: How Religion Poisons Everything
God is not Great: How Religion Poisons Everything

bonuses.leadin: Putting a square matrix in upper-triangular form puts these values in the diagonal. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify these numbers symbolized lambda, which for a square matrix A and some vector x, satisfy the relation A times x equals lambda times x.
By the Cayley-Hamilton theorem, eigenvalues are roots of this polynomial, which is defined as the determinant of the quantity lambda times the identity matrix minus A.
For a matrix A defined on a field F, this is the polynomial P over F with smallest degree such that P of A is equal to zero. Turns out of lambda is a root of this polynomial, it's also an eigenvalue.

bonuses.leadin: This man is often credited with codifying the theory of tonal music in his Treatise on Harmony. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this French composer who, though perhaps better known for his operas, also composed much harpsichord music like "La Rappel des Oiseaux" and "La Poule," in addition to Pieces de clavecin en concerts.

Rameau is sometimes considered the successor to this Italian-born French composer credited with bringing opera to France. You probably know him better for dying of gangrene after he stabbed his foot with a conducting staff.

Both Lully and Rameau are famous for their takes on this dance in simple meter, which like the menuet and the bouree was often placed in the fifth section of the baroque suite, between the sarabande and gigue. Bach's 5th and 6th cello suites both feature these dances.

bonuses.leadin: This figure regretted allowing Charles de La Tour to land in Bostson and recruit men to try and retake Acadia from Charles d'Aulnay. For 10 points each:
answers: John Winthrop [do not accept answers including "Younger"]
parts: Name this leading colonial figure of the Massachusetts Bay Colony. Because of his Puritan values, he opposed the Antinomian ideas of Henry Vane and Anne Hutchingson.
Governor Winthrop used this term in his sermon "A Model of Christian Charity" delivered on the Arbella to the Bay Colonists before arrival. It represented how they would be watched by the world.
Winthrop's Fleet arrived to find that this Anglican clergyman had already settled the Bay Area with his fortified Palisade House on Noddle's Island.

bonuses.leadin: During the wedding of this figure's sister to King Matholwch, Efnisen mutilates a bunch of Mathlowch's horses, leading to this figure offering Mathlowch a magical cauldron. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Welsh giant, whose severed head protects Britain from harm.
The tale of Bran and Mathlowch comprises the second branch of this cycle of Welsh myths, which was translated into English by Charlotte Guest. Its first branch tells the story of Pwyll.
Another story in the Mabinogion tells the story of this cousin of King Arthur and son of Cilydd, who is cursed by his stepmother to only be able to marry the daughter of the giant Ysbaddaden.

bonuses.leadin: The author reflects, "Here stood that Trunk, and there that chest, before declaring, "Adieu, Adieu, All's Vanity." For ten points each:
answers: "Verses Upon the Burning of our House, July 18th, 1666"
parts: Name this poem that begins with screams in the night and concludes with the line, "My hope and treasure lie above."
Verses Upon the Burning of our House" was written by this "Tenth Muse" who sprang up in America.
This Bradstreet poem uses a whole lot of money and debt imagery to show marital affection. It begins, "If ever two were one, then surely we."
answers_formatted: "Verses Upon the Burning of our House, July 18th, 1666"
acceptable: "Verses Upon the Burning of our House, July 18th, 1666"
"Verses Upon the Burning of our House, July 18th, 1666"

bonuses.leadin: C. elegans is a member of this phylum, marine examples of which often have renette glands to secrete salt. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this phylum of invertebrates, commonly known as roundworms. The Mesorhabditis genus of these organisms do not actually fuse eggs and sperm at fertilization.
Nematodes contain a pseudo- version of this central body cavity, which originally arose in triploblastic animals but was subsequently mutated out in many lines. It is usually present in the mesoderm.

Some nematodes, tardigrades, and bdelloid rotifers are able to undergo this state in chronically hot and dessicating conditions. In this state, water is replaced by trehalose solution to place the organisms' cells into suspended animation.

bonuses.leadin: After the English Wars of the Roses, an English family aligned with the Lancasters gained control of the English throne. For 10 points each:
answers: Tudor Dynasty or House of Tudor

his chief minister of Henry VIII orchestrated the English Reformation and helped Henry VIII annul one of his marriages. He was executed when the marriage he arranged between Henry and Anne of Cleves turned sour.
parts: Name this dynasty founded in 1485 and dissolved in 1603, which was succeeded by the House of Stuart.
This Tudor King of England is well known for his marital troubles, which led him to launch the English Reformation.

This chief minister of Henry VIII orchestrated the English Reformation and helped Henry VIII annul one of his marriages. He was executed when the marriage he arranged between Henry and Anne of Cleves turned sour.
answers_formatted: his chief minister of Henry VIII orchestrated the English Reformation and helped Henry VIII annul one of his marriages. He was executed when the marriage he arranged between Henry and Anne of Cleves turned sour.
acceptable: Tudor Dynasty or House of Tudor
Tudor Dynasty or House of Tudor

his chief minister of Henry VIII orchestrated the English Reformation and helped Henry VIII annul one of his marriages. He was executed when the marriage he arranged between Henry and Anne of Cleves turned sour.

his chief minister of Henry VIII orchestrated the English Reformation and helped Henry VIII annul one of his marriages. He was executed when the marriage he arranged between Henry and Anne of Cleves turned sour.

bonuses.leadin: NaCl is held together by this type of bond, which occurs when one atom outright gives an electron to another. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this type of bond which brings a positively charged and negatively charged species together. This type of bond occurs between atoms which have a large difference in electronegativity.
The stability of an ionic solid can be determined by calculating this quantity, which is the energy released with a gaseous ion is added to the solid. It is measured using the Born-Haber cycle.

This equation states that the lattice energy is proportional to the product of the charge on the anion times the charge on the cation, times Coulomb's constant, times Madelung's constant, over the square of the distance between the centers of the atoms.

bonuses.leadin: With her husband Erskine Caldwell, this artist compiled a series about Depression-era Southerners entitled You Have Seen Their Faces, and she also captured the German invasion of Moscow. 10 points each:
parts: Name this photographer, who depicted Mahatma Gandhi at his spinning wheel.
Bourke-White provided the photograph for the cover of the first issue of this Henry Luce-edited photojournalism magazine. It famously ran the photograph of the nurse and sailor kissing on V-J Day.

This war photographer and frequent contributor to Life Magazine took a series of photographs of the D-Day landing. He also depicted a soldier with his rifle outstretched as he died in the Spanish Civil War.

bonuses.leadin: He negotiated the Peace of the Pyrenees and the formation of the League of the Rhine. For 10 points each:
answers: Cardinal Jules Mazarin or Giulio Mazarini
Armand-Jean du Plessis, Cardinal and Duke of Richelieu [accept Red Eminence or L'Ã©minence Rouge]
parts: Name this man who dealt with the Fronde of the Parlement and that of the Nobles. He served as Chief Minister during the regency of Anne of Austria and the young Louis XIV.

Mazarin's predecessor won the trust of Marie de Medicis for negotiating favorable terms for her during this treaty, such as a court at Angers, that ended enmity between the Queen Regent and Louis XIII.
This negotiator of that treaty was almost deposed during the Cinq-Mars conspiracy and the Day of Dupes. This predecessor of Mazarin personally commanded the siege of La Rochelle for Louis XIII.
answers_formatted: Armand-Jean du Plessis, Cardinal and Duke of Richelieu [accept Red Eminence or L'Ã©minence Rouge]
acceptable: Cardinal Jules Mazarin or Giulio Mazarini
Cardinal Jules Mazarin or Giulio Mazarini
Armand-Jean du Plessis, Cardinal and Duke of Richelieu
Armand-Jean du Plessis, Cardinal and Duke of Richelieu

bonuses.leadin: Daniel Dennett's Elbow Room concerns the varieties of this concept which are "worth having." For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this concept which is reconciled with determinism in compatibilist theories of it.

This philosopher argued that the freedom of the will could not be proven from the evidence of self-consciousness in his aptly titled On the Freedom of the Will. You might know him better for writing The World as Will and Idea and hating women.

This paradox concerning free will and popularized by Robert Nozick posits an omniscient being that places before you two boxes, an open one with $1000 and a closed one which contains $1 million if the being predicted you would take the closed one, but nothing if it predicted you would take both.

bonuses.leadin: The protagonist of this novel invents his own namesake Patent Small-Clothes. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this novel in which Theodore Gumbril uses a fake beard to disguise himself as "The Complete Man" when approaching women.
This English author of Antic Hay is better known for writing about John the Savage and Mustapha Mond in Brave New World.
Brave New World focuses on John's romantic interactions with this female character who is called a "strumpet" and locks herself in her own bathroom.

bonuses.leadin: This documentary takes place over the course of one year, and depicts both igloo-building and fishing. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this documentary filmed in Quebec, about an Inuk man and his family. Its creator, Robert Flaherty, was criticized for staging several parts of it.
Nanook of the North was a classic example of this type of ethnography, which attempts to preserve and record the traditions of dying cultures.
One proponent of salvage ethnography was this anthropologist, who studied the Kula ring exchange in his work Argonauts of the Western Pacific.

bonuses.leadin: Events in this series of books include the Red Wedding of Lord Walder Frey and the hiring of the Unsullied by Daenerys Targaryen. For 10 points each:
answers: A Song of Ice and Fire [accept ASOIAF or equivalents]
The King's Hand [or the Hand of the King]
parts: Name this popular fantasy series by George R.R. Martin dealing with the political intrigues and civil wars of the Seven Kingdoms on the continent of Westeros. Its first book is titled Game of Thrones.

One important motif of the series is the start of this long time period that "is coming" according to the Stark family motto. During it wights, Others, and other threats from beyond the Wall increase.

Ser Davos served in this position for Stannis Baratheon. Tyrion Lannister and by his father Tywinn both once held this office. Other holders of this advisory position included Jon Arryn and Ned Stark.
answers_formatted: A Song of Ice and Fire [accept ASOIAF or equivalents]
The King's Hand [or the Hand of the King]
acceptable: A Song of Ice and Fire
